pico.title: Differential Privacy for Satellite-Derived Climate Data Products: A Scoping Review
pico.population: Gridded climate and environmental data products derived from satellite observations at fine spatial and temporal resolution, including land surface temperature, precipitation estimates, vegetation indices (NDVI, EVI), soil moisture, snow cover, atmospheric composition, and derived climate indicators used in research, agriculture, water management, and infrastructure planning
pico.intervention: Differential privacy mechanisms applied to climate data products before public release, including spatial noise addition (Laplace, Gaussian), temporal perturbation, resolution coarsening with privacy guarantees, and synthetic climate data generation with formal privacy bounds
pico.comparison: Different epsilon (Îµ) values ranging from 0.1 (strong privacy) to 10 (weak privacy); spatial vs. temporal vs. combined noise addition strategies; different noise mechanisms; unprotected release baseline; traditional resolution-limited release without formal guarantees
pico.outcome: Scientific utility for climate applications (trend detection accuracy, anomaly identification, extreme event detection), formal privacy guarantee strength, downstream model performance (crop yield models, hydrological simulations, energy demand forecasting), spatial and temporal correlation preservation, and practical feasibility for operational climate services
pico.research_question: For satellite-derived climate data products at fine spatial resolution, how do differential privacy mechanisms at various epsilon levels affect the scientific utility for detecting climate trends, anomalies, and extreme events while providing formal privacy guarantees?
pico.rationale: High-resolution satellite-derived climate data can reveal sensitive information including military installation activity patterns (thermal signatures), industrial operations (emissions, heat), agricultural practices, and infrastructure vulnerabilities. Some data providers require formal privacy guarantees before sharing fine-resolution products. Additionally, as climate data increasingly underpins commercial decisions (energy trading, insurance, agriculture), privacy becomes relevant to protect proprietary ground-truth data contributing to satellite product calibration. Understanding privacy-utility trade-offs enables evidence-based decisions about climate data distribution policies.

sub_questions.title: Impact on Climate Trend Detection
sub_questions.population: Multi-decadal satellite-derived temperature and vegetation index time series
sub_questions.intervention: Differential privacy with epsilon values from 0.5 to 5.0 applied to annual/seasonal aggregates
sub_questions.comparison: Original data trend analysis vs. differentially private versions
sub_questions.outcome: Trend magnitude estimation bias, statistical significance preservation, trend detection power, Type I and Type II error rates
sub_questions.research_question: How does differential privacy affect the ability to detect and quantify long-term climate trends in satellite-derived data products?

sub_questions.title: Extreme Event Detection Preservation
sub_questions.population: High-resolution satellite products used for detecting climate extremes (heatwaves, droughts, floods)
sub_questions.intervention: Differential privacy mechanisms with various noise distributions
sub_questions.comparison: Laplace vs. Gaussian noise; truncated vs. unbounded noise; different epsilon values
sub_questions.outcome: Extreme event detection sensitivity and specificity, false alarm rate, event magnitude estimation accuracy, spatial extent estimation
sub_questions.research_question: Which differential privacy mechanisms best preserve the ability to detect climate extremes while providing formal privacy guarantees?

sub_questions.title: Downstream Model Performance
sub_questions.population: Climate-dependent models using satellite-derived inputs (crop models, hydrological models, energy demand models)
sub_questions.intervention: Differentially private climate inputs at various epsilon levels
sub_questions.comparison: Model performance with original vs. private inputs; different model types and sensitivities
sub_questions.outcome: Model output accuracy degradation, uncertainty propagation, decision-relevance threshold identification
sub_questions.research_question: How does differential privacy in satellite-derived climate inputs propagate through downstream models, and what epsilon values maintain decision-relevant accuracy?
